articles.title: WHAT'S GOING ON IN THE CLUB:
articles.summary: This club newsletter outlines upcoming activities for March and April, including general membership meetings featuring talks on celestial charts and Venus probes, an informal equipment night, and mirror-making workshops. Members are encouraged to participate in public outreach at Canoas Elementary School and several star parties at Fremont Peak and Skyline. Additionally, the article shares recent astronomical news regarding Saturn's newly confirmed moons, observed albedo variations and cloud activity on Neptune, and updated rotation periods for Uranus and Neptune.

articles.title: Red Spot times
articles.summary: This document provides a detailed schedule of observed or predicted 'Red Spot times' for the month of March, primarily in PST. It includes specific dates, times, visual magnitude, illumination, elevation, and other relevant notes for each event. A second, smaller table also lists additional date and time entries.

articles.title: White spot
articles.summary: This document provides a schedule for observing a 'White spot' across various dates in March, listing specific times. It also details observation opportunities for the spectroscopic binary λ Virginis and the visual binary ⍵ Leonis, providing their characteristics. Additionally, the article describes a challenging twilight occultation of the M25 galactic cluster, offering observing tips and highlighting its significance as the last such event of the year.

articles.title: JUPITER
articles.summary: Jim Van Nuland is seeking observations of Jupiter's Red Spot and a white spot from October 24, as his own viewing attempts have been hindered by poor seeing conditions. He requests other observers to contact him with timings to help maintain his predictions, noting that no fancy equipment is required. Additionally, he advises watching for the moon close to Jupiter on March 23 and 24.

articles.title: SOLAR ECLIPSE
articles.summary: This document announces an 11-day cruise to Mexico aboard Sitmar's TSS FAIRSEA, departing from Los Angeles on October 8th, specifically for viewing a total solar eclipse at sea on October 12th. The voyage offers a unique opportunity to experience the eclipse with renowned scientific authorities like Dr. Joseph M. Chamberlain, Dr. George Abell, Dr. J. Allen Hynek, and Dr. James Sadler, alongside cultural and recreational activities in Mexican ports. Officially endorsed by W.A.A. and N.A.N.C., the cruise promises an enriching blend of astronomy, education, and leisure.

articles.title: CATEGORY AND DECK | REGULAR COST | SPECIAL COST TO MEMBERS
articles.summary: This document outlines detailed pricing for various cruise cabin categories, differentiating between regular and special member costs based on occupancy and deck location. The rates include accommodations, meals, entertainment, and specialized astronomical/photographic lectures, complemented by "Fly Free" airfare options from specific major airports and reduced fares from other cities.

articles.title: SITMARCRUISES
articles.summary: This document is an advertisement for SITMAR*CRUISES, offering special, limited-space rates to members and their families. It includes a reservation form requiring a $100 per person deposit, with instructions to make checks payable to ALL POINTS TRAVEL and send to their San Mateo address. Contact information for further inquiries is also provided.

articles.title: Northern Section (Top)
articles.summary: This document consists of fragmented internal notes pertaining to a "Northern Section" located in the Livermore area, referencing an entity named "SAQA". It lists specific points of interest within this area and outlines a route to San Francisco using several major highways. The precise purpose or context of these logistical notes is not explicitly detailed.

articles.title: Western Section (Left)
articles.summary: The document provides geographical and navigational details for the 'Western Section,' specifically focusing on Saratoga and Los Gatos. For Saratoga, it lists an elevation of 2621 ft, references Skyline Blvd., and a distance of 1.9 miles. For Los Gatos, it notes its proximity to Saratoga, mentions Hwy 9, and describes a route from Big Basin to Santa Cruz, suggesting travel or location-based information.

articles.title: Central Section
articles.summary: This document identifies a 'Central Section' focusing on geographical locations in California. Key points listed include San Jose, Capri Resort & Ranch, Morgan Hill, Gilroy, and East Dunne Avenue.

articles.title: Southern Section (Bottom)
articles.summary: This document describes a "Southern Section," detailing points of interest in the San Juan Bautista and Fremont Peak areas. It mentions San Juan Bautista's proximity to Monterey and provides details for Fremont Peak, including an overflow area, Coulter camp, a photo area, a ranger's home, and its elevation of 3169.

articles.title: SAN JOSE AMATEUR ASTRONOMERS - MARCH 1977
articles.summary: This document presents a membership roster for the San Jose Amateur Astronomers, dated March 1977. It includes a comprehensive list of members' names, addresses, cities, zip codes, and phone numbers, primarily covering the greater San Jose, California area and surrounding communities.
